case_vignette: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-month history of abdominal discomfort, fatigue, and increased urinary frequency, especially at night. He has also noticed that despite eating more often he has lost 14-lbs (6-kg). He has a congenital solitary kidney and a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis, for which he takes levothyroxine. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 10 years. BMI is 18 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum studies show an osmolality of 305 mOsm/L and bicarbonate of 17 mEq/L. Urinalysis shows clear-colored urine with no organisms.
question: Which  is most likely to be helpful in establishing the diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having abdominal discomfort, feeling tired more often, and needing to urinate more, especially at night, over the past two months.
Have you noticed any blood in your urine or any changes in your urine color?
No, there's no blood and the color of my urine is clear.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle?
I've actually been eating more often but I still ended up losing weight.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or any new medications you've started taking?
No, there haven't been any changes to my medications; I'm just taking levothyroxine for my thyroid condition.
Have you had any family history of kidney disease or any other medical conditions?
I'm not sure about my family history, but I was born with only one kidney.
Final Diagnosis: Unilateral Nephrectomy.
